y.explanation: The 25th letter of the modern English alphabet.
Any of the speech sounds represented by the letter y.
The 25th in a series.
Something shaped like the letter Y.
electricity , the symbol for admittance , in alternating-current circuits. See admittance , 6.
lowercase ] An abbreviation of yard .

lowercase or cap. ] A corruption of the Anglo-Saxon character , equivalent to th , giving ye for the or thee ; and, by contraction, ym for them; yn for then; yr for their; ys for this; yt for that. See def. 1.
Something resembling the letter Y in shape.
See i- . For Middle English words with this prefix, see i- , or the form without the prefix.

A very common suffix used to form adjectives from nouns, and sometimes from verbs, such adjectives denoting ‘having,’ ‘covered with,’ ‘full of,’ etc., the thing expressed by the noun, as in stony, rocky, icy, watery, rainy, dewy, meaty, juicy, mealy, salty, peppery, powdery, flowery, spotty, speckly , etc.

A diminutive suffix, appearing chiefly in childish names of animals, etc., as kitty, doggy, piggy, birdy, froggy, mousy , and similar names, or familiar forms of personal names, as Katy or Kitty (diminutive of Kate ), Jenny, Hetty, Fanny, Willy, Johnny, Tommy , etc., such names being often spelled with - ie , as Willie, Davie , etc., a spelling common in Scotch use, and also in general use in names of girls, as Katie, Jennie, Hettie, Carrie, Lizzie, Nellie, Annie , etc.
A termination of nouns from the Latin or Greek, or of modern formation on the Latin or Greek model.
An old mode of writing the pronoun I.
chem. , the symbol of yttrium.
ornithology , in myological formulas, the symbol of the accessory semitendinosus.
mathematics :
lowercase ] In algebra, the second of the variables or unknown quantities.
lowercase ] In analytical geometry, the symbol of the ordinate or other rectilinear point-coördinate.
y.
lowercase ] An abbreviation of year .
Guide to Pronunciation , §§ 145, 178-9, 272.
I.
One of the forked holders for supporting the telescope of a leveling instrument, or the axis of a theodolite; a wye.
A forked or bifurcated pipe fitting.
A portion of track consisting of two diverging tracks connected by a cross track.
an instrument for measuring differences of level by means of a telescope resting in Y's.

a handsome European noctuid moth Plusia gamma ) which has a bright, silvery mark, shaped like the letter Y, on each of the fore wings. Its larva, which is green with five dorsal white species, feeds on the cabbage, turnip, bean, etc. Called also gamma moth , and silver Y .
The twenty-fifth letter of the basic modern Latin alphabet .
Symbol for the prefix yocto- .
close front rounded vowel
Denoting an item that is twenty-fifth in a list.
The twenty-fifth letter of the English alphabet , called wye and written in the Latin script .
Abbreviation of year .
Abbreviation of youth ., usually followed by an age appropriate for the content so marked.
Abbreviation of yes .
Abbreviation of why .?
the 25th letter of the Roman alphabet
a silvery metallic element that is common in rare-earth minerals; used in magnesium and aluminum alloys

ya.explanation: In chem. , the designation first given by Marignac in 1880 to the metal now known as gadolinium , its oxid having been obtained, along with that of yttrium and other elements of the same group, from the samarskite of North Carolina.

yabber.explanation: To talk or converse rapidly or casually.
The language or talk of the Australian aborigines.

yabbered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yabber .

yabbers.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of yabber .

yabby.explanation: Any of several freshwater crayfish of the genus Cherax of Australia, especially C. destructor, commonly raised for food.
In Australia, a crawfish, Astacopsis bicarinatus.

yacare.explanation: A South American crocodilian ( Jacare sclerops ) resembling the alligator in size and habits. The eye orbits are connected together, and surrounded by prominent bony ridges. Called also spectacled alligator , and spectacled cayman .
A caiman ; a kind of alligator .

yacca.explanation: Either of two West Indian evergreens, Podocarpus Purdieana and P. coriacea , trees becoming respectively 100 feet and 50 feet high, and affording timber suitable for cabinet and plain purposes.
A West Indian name for two large timber trees ( Podocarpus coriaceus , and Podocarpus Purdicanus ) of the Yew family. The wood, which is much used, is pale brownish with darker streaks.
Either of two large evergreens of the West Indies , Podocarpus coriaceus and Podocarpus purdicanus.
Any of the various Australian perennial flowering plants of the genus Xanthorrhoea
West Indian evergreen with medium to long leaves

yacht.explanation: Any of various relatively small, streamlined sailing or motor-driven vessels used for pleasure cruises or racing.
To sail, cruise, or race in a yacht.

A vessel propelled either by sails or by steam, most often light or comparatively small, but sometimes of large size, used for pleasure-trips or for racing, or as a vessel of state to convey persons of distinction by water.
To manage a yacht; to voyage in a yacht.

A light and elegantly furnished vessel, used either for private parties of pleasure, or as a vessel of state to convey distinguished persons from one place to another; a seagoing vessel used only for pleasure trips, racing, etc.
A slick and light ship for making pleasure trips or racing on water, having sails but often motor-powered. At times used as a residence offshore on a dock (Wikipedia).
Any vessel used for private, noncommercial purposes.
To sail , voyage , or race in a yacht.
an expensive vessel propelled by sail or power and used for cruising or racing

yachted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yacht .

yachter.explanation: One who commands a yacht; also, one who sails in a yacht; a yachtsman.
One engaged in sailing a jacht.
A person who sails in yachts .

yachting.explanation: The art of navigating a yacht; the sport of sailing of traveling in a yacht. Also used attributively: as, a yachting voyage; a yachting suit.
Sailing for pleasure in a yacht.
A physical activity involving boats , be it racing sailing boats, cruising to distant shores, or day-sailing along a coast.

yachts.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of yacht .

yachtsman.explanation: A man who owns or sails a yacht.
One who keeps or sails a yacht.
One who owns or sails a yacht; a yachter.
A man who sails a yacht .
a person who owns or sails a yacht

yachtsmanship.explanation: The art or science of sailing or managing a yacht. Also yachtmanship .
The ability or art of being adept at sailing a yacht

yachtswoman.explanation: A woman who owns or sails a yacht.
A woman who sails a yacht .
a person who owns or sails a yacht

yack.explanation: to vomit , usually because of intoxication

yacked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yack .

yacks.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of yack .

yad.explanation: An ornamented pointer used to mark one's place when reading out loud from a scroll of the Torah in a synagogue.

A small tapering hand with outstretched index-finger, made of precious metal or ivory, beautifully carved. It is used to indicate the words to the reader while he is reading the Scriptures in the synagogue from the scroll called Sepher Torah .
A pointer used in the ritual of Torah -reading.
The letter ⴷ in the Tifinagh alphabet.

yaffingale.explanation: the European green woodpecker , Picus viridis

yaffle.explanation: The green woodpecker, Gecinus viridis : from its loud laughing notes. Also yaffil, yaffler, yaffingale. See cut under popinjay .
A pile of codfish to be carried from the flakes to the storehouse.

The European green woodpecker ( Picus viridis syn. Genius viridis ). It is noted for its loud laughlike note. Called also eccle , hewhole , highhoe , laughing bird , popinjay , rain bird , yaffil , yaffler , yaffingale , yappingale , yackel , and woodhack .
the European green woodpecker , Picus viridis

yaffler.explanation: the European green woodpecker , Picus viridis

yager.explanation: Formerly, a member of various bodies of light infantry in the armies of different German states, recruited largely from foresters, etc.; now, a member of certain special battalions or corps of infantry or cavalry, generally organized as riflemen.
In the German army, one belonging to a body of light infantry armed with rifles, resembling the chasseur of the French army.
A Jäger , an elite soldier of the Austrian army

yagger.explanation: A ranger about the country; a traveling peddler.

yagi.explanation: A directional radio antenna consisting of a parallel array of similar elements in which only one element is directly connected to the feed line from the receiver or transmitter.
A directional radio or TV antenna consisting of two or more dipoles in the same plane with all dipoles parallel to each other.

yaguarundi.explanation: A wild cat of Mexico and Central and South America, Felis jaguarundi.

yah.explanation: An upper-class person, especially a Sloane Ranger .

yahoo.explanation: A name given by Swift, in “Gulliver's Travels,” to a feigned race of brutes having the form of man and all his degrading passions.
[ lowercase ] A rough, brutal, uncouth character.
[ lowercase ] A greenhorn; a back-country lout.
One of a race of filthy brutes in Swift's “Gulliver's Travels.” See in the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction.
Hence, any brutish or vicious character.
A raw countryman; a lout; a greenhorn.
A rough , coarse , or uncouth person; yokel ; lout .
A derogatory term for a white person from the Confederate South (i.e., United States).
A humanoid cryptid said to exist in parts of eastern Australia, and also reported in the Bahamas.
one of a race of brutes resembling men but subject to the Houyhnhnms in a novel by Jonathan Swift
a person who is not very intelligent or interested in culture
a widely used search engine for the web that finds information, news, images, products, finance

yahooism.explanation: The behaviour or attitudes of yahoos ; ignorant boorishness .

yahrzeit.explanation: The anniversary of a person's death, often of a parent's.

yahveh.explanation: a name for the God of the Old Testament as transliterated from the Hebrew consonants YHVH

yahwism.explanation: Yahweh as a name of God.

yajna.explanation: A ritual of sacrifice to the Devas .

yak.explanation: A wild, shaggy-haired ox (Bos grunniens) of the mountains of central Asia.
A domesticated yak, used as a work animal or raised for meat and milk.
To talk persistently and meaninglessly; chatter.
The wild ox of Tibet, Poëphagus grunniens , or any of its domesticated varieties; the grunting ox.

A bovine mammal ( Poëphagus grunnies ) native of the high plains of Central Asia. Its neck, the outer side of its legs, and its flanks, are covered with long, flowing, fine hair. Its tail is long and bushy, often white, and is valued as an ornament and for other purposes in India and China. There are several domesticated varieties, some of which lack the mane and the long hair on the flanks. Called also chauri gua , grunting cow , grunting ox , sarlac , sarlik , and sarluc .
a coarse pillow lace made from the silky hair of the yak.
An ox -like mammal native to the Himalayas and Tibet with dark, long and silky hair a horse like tail and a full, bushy mane.
To talk , particularly informally but persistently, such as chatter .
To vomit , usually as a result of excessive alcohol consumption.
A talk , particular an informal one such as chattering .
large long-haired wild ox of Tibet often domesticated

yakalo.explanation: A hybrid cross of a yak (Bos grunniens) and an American bison (Bison bison).

yakamik.explanation: A bird allied to the cranes ; the agami or trumpeter .

yakin.explanation: A large Himalayan antelope, Budorcas taxicolor , inhabiting high mountain-ranges.

A large Asiatic antelope ( Budorcas taxicolor ) native of the higher parts of the Himalayas and other lofty mountains. Its head and neck resemble those of the ox, and its tail is like that of the goat. Called also budorcas .
A large Himalayan antelope , Budorcas taxicolor

yakitori.explanation: A dish of bite-sized marinated chicken pieces grilled on skewers.
A Japanese shishkabob -type dish made with small pieces of chicken, fish, vegetables or beef which have been marinated in soy sauce and then cooked on skewers.

yakked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yak .

yakker.explanation: One who yaks ; a chatterbox or motormouth .

yaksha.explanation: In Hindu mythology , one of a class of demigods who attend Kuvera, the god of riches, and guard his treasures.
A kind of demigod attendant on Kuvera, the god of wealth.
a spirit that watches over the treasures hidden in the earth and tree roots

yali.explanation: A type of house , particularly found on the Bosporus.

yam.explanation: Any of numerous chiefly tropical vines of the genus Dioscorea, many of which have edible tuberous roots.
The starchy root of any of these plants, used in the tropics as food.
A tuberous root of a plant of the genus Dioscorea , particularly if belonging to one of numerous species cultivated for their esculent roots; also, such a plant itself.
By transference, a variety of the sweet-potato.
Any plant of the order Dioscoreaceæ.

A large, esculent, farinaceous tuber of various climbing plants of the genus Dioscorea; also, the plants themselves. Mostly natives of warm climates. The plants have netted-veined, petioled leaves, and pods with three broad wings. The commonest species is Dioscorea sativa , but several others are cultivated.
Any one of several cultural varieties of the sweet potato.
a plant ( Dioscorea Batatas ) with a long and slender tuber, hardier than most of the other species.
An orchidaceous plant ( Gastrodia sesamoides ) of Australia and Tasmania.
Any climbing vine of the genus Dioscorea in the Eastern and Western hemispheres, usually cultivated
The edible, starchy, tuberous root of that plant, a tropical staple food.
A sweet potato ; a tuber from the genus Ipomoea .
any of a number of tropical vines of the genus Dioscorea many having edible tuberous roots
sweet potato with deep orange flesh that remains moist when baked
edible tuberous root of various yam plants of the genus Dioscorea grown in the tropics world-wide for food
edible tuber of any of several yams

yamen.explanation: The office or residence of an official in the Chinese Empire.
A common, but misleading, spelling of yamun . See yamun .
In China, the official headquarters or residence of a mandarin, including court rooms, offices, gardens, prisons, etc.; the place where the business of any public department is transcated.
A residence of an official of the Chinese Empire.

yammer.explanation: To talk volubly and often loudly.
To utter or say loudly or in a complaining tone.
To repeat on and on, usually loudly or in complaint .
To make an outcry ; to clamor .
The act or noise of yammering .

yammered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yammer .

yammerer.explanation: One who complains or whines peevishly or whimperingly.

yammers.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of yammer .

yamp.explanation: An umbelliferous plant, Carum Gairdneri , found from California to Wyoming and Washington; doubtless, also, C. Kellogii , of central California. These plants have fascicled tuberous roots, which are an important food of the Indians.
An umbelliferous plant ( Carum Gairdneri ); also, its small fleshy roots, which are eaten by the Indians from Idaho to California.
An umbelliferous plant , Perideridia gairdneri, native to California , whose tubers were used as food by Native Americans

yampee.explanation: A variety of yam , scientific name Dioscorea trifida, smaller than a regular yam.

yamstchik.explanation: In 19th century Russia, someone who delivers post by means of a horse-drawn carriage .

yamun.explanation: The official and private residence of a Chinese mandarin who holds a seal; the place where a mandarin transacts the business of the region or department under his care, and where he lives; a mandarin's office, court, residence, etc.
Various transliterations of the Chinese word are in use: yamun , which is to be preferred
yamăn , used by Dr. S. Wells Williams in his “Dictionary of the Chinese Language”

yamen , originally introduced by Sir Thomas F. Wade, former British Minister in Peking, and now used in the diplomatic, consular, and customs' services of China: it is more particularly characteristic of the Pekingese “dialect”
yamen , which is the same as the preceding with the circumflex omitted, owing to the poverty of the type-fonts used in type-setting machines
yamön , the form preferred by Prof. F. Hirth of Columbia University, New York. In every case the pronunciation is the same.
An official residence provided for Chinese officials

yan.explanation: one in Cumbrian sheep counting rhyme.

yana.explanation: Any of the three vehicles of Buddhist practice; Mahayana , Hinayana , and Vajrayana .

yanan.explanation: a language group of the Hokan family

yang.explanation: The active, male cosmic principle in Chinese dualistic philosophy.

The cry of the wild goose; a honk.
To make the cry of the wild goose.
one of the two fundamental principles. See yin and yang .
To make the cry of the wild goose .
The essential male principle in eastern religion or philosophy.

the bright positive masculine principle in Chinese dualistic cosmology

yank.explanation: To pull with a quick, strong movement; jerk.
A sudden vigorous pull; a jerk.
along, over , or out : as, to yank a fish out of the water.
A quick, sharp stroke; a buffet.
plural Leggings or long gaiters worn in England by agricultural laborers.

[The word acquired during the war of the rebellion wide currency as a nickname or contemptuous epithet among the Confederates for a Union soldier, the Confederates themselves being in like spirit dubbed Johnnies or Rebs by the Union soldiers.]
A sudden , vigorous pull (sometimes defined as mass times jerk , or rate of change of force ).
To pull something with a quick , strong action .
pull, or move with a sudden movement
an American who lives in the North (especially during the American Civil War)

yanked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yank .

yankeedom.explanation: The region inhabited by Yankees, in any sense of that word.

yanker.explanation: Someone who yanks , or gives a sudden hard pull
someone who gives a strong sudden pull

yanks.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of yank .

yanky.explanation: A Dutch craft of a kind not definitely known.

yanqui.explanation: A citizen of the United States of America as opposed to a Latin American .

yantra.explanation: A geometrical diagram used as a meditation aid in tantric worship.
Any object used as a meditation aid in tantric worship.

yaourt.explanation: A kind of thickened fermented liquor made by the Turks of milk curdled in a special way.
A fermented drink, or milk beer, made by the Turks.
A liquor fermented from milk , originally by the Turks .

yap.explanation: To bark sharply or shrilly; yelp.
To talk noisily or stupidly; jabber.
A sharp, shrill bark; a yelp.
A stupid, crude, or loud person.
A yelp, as of a dog.
The high-pitched bark of a small dog .
A badly behaved child , a brat .
Of a small dog , to bark .

yapman.explanation: A native of Yap, one of the Caroline Islands.

yapock.explanation: A South American aquatic opossum ( Chironectes variegatus ) found in Guiana and Brazil. Its hind feet are webbed, and its fore feet do not have an opposable thumb for climbing. Called also water opossum .

yapok.explanation: An aquatic opossum (Chironectes minimus) of tropical regions of the Americas, having dense fur, webbed hind feet, and a long tail.
The South American water-opossum, Chironectes variegatus.

yapon.explanation: An evergreen shrub or small tree of the holly kind, Ilex vomitoria , better known as I. Cassine , found from Virginia around the coast to Texas, thence to Arkansas.

yapped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yap .

yapper.explanation: One's mouth , especially of a gossipy person.

yappy.explanation: Of a dog, yapping in an annoying manner.
Very talkative ; talking foolishly or at length.

yar.explanation: To growl , especially like a dog; quarrel ; be captious or troublesome .
Quick and agile; easy to hand , reef and steer .

yarak.explanation: A super-alert state where the bird is hungry, but not weak, and ready to hunt .

yarborough.explanation: A bridge or whist hand containing no honor cards.

In whist or bridge , a hand which contains no card above a nine: so called because a former Earl of Yarborough made a practice of betting 1,000 to 1 against any player's holding such a hand. The true odds against it are 1,827 to 1.
A hand , in bridge or whist , that has no card with a value greater than nine

yard.explanation: A fundamental unit of length in both the US Customary System and the British Imperial System, equal to 3 feet, or 36 inches (0.9144 meter).
A long tapering spar slung to a mast to support and spread the head of a square sail, lugsail, or lateen.
A square yard.
A cubic yard.
A tract of ground next to, surrounding, or surrounded by a building or buildings.
A tract of ground, often enclosed, used for a specific business or activity.
A baseball park.
An area where railroad trains are made up and cars are switched, stored, and serviced on tracks and sidings.
A winter pasture for deer or other grazing animals.
An enclosed tract of ground in which animals, such as chickens or pigs, are kept.
To enclose, collect, or put into a yard.
To gather together into a yard.
yard cows.
A rod; a stick; a wand; a branch or twig.
Rule; direction; correction.
A measuring-rod or -stick of the exact length of 3 feet or 36 imperial inches; a yardstick.
The fundamental unit of English long measure.

Nautical , a long cylindrical spar having a rounded taper toward each end, slung crosswise to a mast and used for suspending certain of the sails called either square or lateen sails according as the yard is suspended at right angles or obliquely.
A long piece of timber, as a rafter.
In heraldry , a bearing representing a staff or wand divided into equal parts, as if for a measure.
The virile member; the penis.
Hence— A pint of ale, beer, or wine served in a yard-glass, and usually drunk for amusement or on a wager, on account of the likelihood of spilling or choking. Compare ale-yard .

A piece of inclosed ground of small or moderate size; particularly, a piece of ground inclosing or adjoining a house or other building, or inclosed by it: as, a front yard ; a court- yard ; a door yard ; a church yard ; an inn- yard ; a barn- yard ; a vine yard.
An inclosure within which any work or business is carried on: as, a brick- yard ; a wood- yard ; a tan- yard ; a dock- yard ; a stock- yard ; a navy- yard.
In railway usage, the space or tract adjacent to a railway station or terminus, which is used for the switching or making up of trains, the accommodation of rolling-stock, and similar purposes.
A garden; now, chiefly, a kitchen- or cottage-garden: as, a kale- yard.
The winter pasture or browsing-ground of moose and deer; a moose-yard.
A measure of land in England, varying locally: in Buckinghamshire, formerly, 28 to 40 acres; in Wiltshire, a quarter of an acre. Compare yard-land .
An inclosure; usually, a small inclosed place in front of, or around, a house or barn
An inclosure within which any work or business is carried on
a liberty, granted to persons imprisoned for debt, of walking in the yard, or within any other limits prescribed by law, on their giving bond not to go beyond those limits.
an inclosure about a prison, or attached to it.
a low-growing grass ( Eleusine Indica ) having digitate spikes. It is common in dooryards, and like places, especially in the Southern United States. Called also crab grass .
See Yardland .
To confine (cattle) to the yard; to shut up, or keep, in a yard.
A rod; a stick; a staff.
A branch; a twig.
A long piece of timber, as a rafter, etc.
A measure of length, equaling three feet, or thirty-six inches, being the standard of English and American measure.
The penis.
A long piece of timber, nearly cylindrical, tapering toward the ends, and designed to support and extend a square sail. A yard is usually hung by the center to the mast. See Illust. of Ship .
A place where moose or deer herd together in winter for pasture, protection, etc.
a popular name of the three stars in the belt of Orion.

yardage.explanation: The use or convenience of a yard or inclosure, as in receiving, lading, or unlading cattle, etc., from railroad-cars.
The charge made for such use or convenience.
In coal-mining , cutting coal at so much per yard or fathom.
An amount or length measured in yards .
distance measured in the aggregate number of yards

yardang.explanation: A long, sharp ridge of soft, clearly differentiated sediments rising between two troughs made by wind or water erosion and extending parallel to the direction of the wind or water flow.
A large wind-eroded mass of soft or poorly consolidated rock in a desert region which lies parallel to the prevailing winds, often with an unusual shape.

yardarm.explanation: Either end of a yard of a square sail.
Either half of a square-rigged vessel's yard{6}, from the center or mast to the end.

The outer quarters of a horizontal spar attached to the mast athwartships , equipped with blocks for reeving signal halyards .
either end of the yard of a square-rigged ship

yardbird.explanation: A soldier who is required to perform menial work on the grounds of a military base.

a military recruit who is assigned menial tasks

yarded.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yard .

yarder.explanation: A motor-driven logging machine which transports logs by means of a system of cables and winches .
Something that is a stated number of yards in some dimension - such as a ten-yarder.
(used only in combinations) the height or length of something in yards
a winch (or system of winches) powered by an engine and used to haul logs from a stump to a landing or to a skid road

yardful.explanation: As much as a yard will contain; enough to fill a yard.

yardgrass.explanation: Eleusine indica , a coarse annual grass often found as a weed
coarse annual grass having fingerlike spikes of flowers; native to Old World tropics; a naturalized weed elsewhere

yardland.explanation: The area of land held by a tenant in villeinage in early English manors, consisting usually of an aggregate of some 30 strips in the open fields with a messuage in the village. In some counties it was 15 acres; in others 20 or 24, and even 40 acres. See holding , 3 . Also yard of land .
A measure of land of uncertain quantity, varying from fifteen to forty acres; a virgate.
A measure of area of land in Medieval England, from 15 to 40 acres but varying in size depending on the region.

yardman.explanation: A man employed in a yard, especially a railroad yard.
The laborer who has the special care of a farm-yard.
One who is employed in a railway-yard under the yard-master, to assist in switching cars and making up trains. Also yardsman .
A laborer hired to do outdoor work .
a laborer hired to do outdoor work (such as mowing lawns)

yardmaster.explanation: A railroad employee in charge of a yard.

a railroad employer who is in charge of a railway yard

yards.explanation: The totality of the sailing rig .

yardstick.explanation: A graduated measuring stick one yard in length.
A test, standard, or model used in measurement, comparison, or judgment.

A stick or rod exactly 3 feet long, generally marked with subdivisions, as quarters and eighths of the yard on the one side, and inches, or perhaps feet and inches, on the other. See yard , n. , 3, 4.
Figuratively, a standard of measurement in general.
A stick three feet, or a yard, in length, used as a measure of cloth, etc.
A measuring rod thirty-six inches long.
A standard to which other measurements or comparisons are judged.
a ruler or tape that is three feet long
a measure or standard used for comparison

yardwork.explanation: Work done in maintaining a lawn , and related landscaping activities

yare.explanation: Responding easily; maneuverable. Used of a vessel.
Ready; dexterous; eager; lively; quick to move.
Eager , keen , lively , handy ; agile , nimble .
Easily manageable and answering readily to the helm ; yar .

yarer.explanation: comparative form of yare : more yare

yareta.explanation: A curious umbelliferous plant, Azorella glebaria , of the high table-land of Peru and Bolivia, where, together with taquia , or llama dung, it is the chief source of fuel.

yark.explanation: To hit , strike , especially with a cane or whip .
To dispose ; be set in order for; be destined or intended for.

yarke.explanation: The black white-headed saki, Pithecia leucocephala , or other member of the same genus.

yarl.explanation: A deep , guttural vocal style with affected pronunciation , characteristic of male grunge and postgrunge singers of the 1990s and early 2000s .

yarm.explanation: To cry out ; make a loud, unpleasant noise ; shriek ; yell .

yarn.explanation: A continuous strand of twisted threads of natural or synthetic fibers, such as wool or nylon, used in weaving or knitting.

yowley.explanation: The yellow bunting, Emberiza citrinella : more fully called, by reduplication, yellow yowley. Also yeldring, yeldrin, yeldrock, yolding, yoldring, yoldrin, yolling, yorling ; also yite, yoit. See cut under yellowhammer .

yowls.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of yowl .

yponomeuta.explanation: A notable genus of tineid moths, typical of the family Yponomeutidæ , comprising a number of rather large slender-bodied species, usually white or gray, and often with many small black spots.

yponomeutid.explanation: A member of the lepidopterous family Yponomeutidæ.

ypsiliform.explanation: Υ ; Y-shaped. The figure is also called arietiform , the symbol of the zodiacal sign Aries being the same.
Resembling the � in appearance; -- said of the germinal spot in the ripe egg at one of the stages of fecundation.
in the shape of an ypsilon

ypsiloid.explanation: In the form of the letter y ; y- shaped.

yr.explanation: a period of time containing 365 (or 366) days

ys.explanation: Symbol for the yoctosecond , an SI unit of time equal to 10−24 seconds .

yt.explanation: An occasional symbol for yttrium. The single letter Y is more generally so used.
that (AS. þæt , ðæt ) the “y” taking the place of the old letter “thorn” (þ). Cf. ye , the.

ytterbia.explanation: In chem. , ytterbium oxid, commonly assumed to be Yb 2 O 3 , which is white, and forms colorless salts, giving no absorption-spectrum; but a characteristic spark-spectrum can be obtained.

ytterbic.explanation: chem. , containing ytterbium as a constituent.
Pertaining to, or derived from, ytterbium; containing ytterbium.

ytterbite.explanation: Gadolinite : a black, vitreous mineral consisting primarily of silicates of various rare earths including ytterbium
a mineral that is a source of rare earths; consists of silicates of iron and beryllium and cerium and yttrium and erbium

ytterbium.explanation: A soft, bright, silvery rare-earth element occurring in three allotropic forms and used as an x-ray source for portable irradiation devices, as a dopant for laser materials, and in solar cells and some special alloys. Atomic number 70; atomic weight 173.05; melting point 824°C; boiling point 1,196°C; specific gravity 6.903 (alpha form), 6.966 (beta form); valence 2, 3. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
Chemical symbol, Yb; atomic weight, 173 (?). An element discovered by Marignac in gadolinite, in regard to which little is known.

In making the ‘glowers’ or filaments for the Nernst incandescent electric lamps it has been found that the mixture of zirconia with the earths of the yttria group gives the most satisfactory results when the latter contain a large proportion of ytterbium as compared with yttrium.
A rare element of the boron group, sometimes associated with yttrium or other related elements, as in euxenite and gadolinite. Symbol Yb; provisional atomic weight 173.2. Cf. yttrium .
A metallic chemical element (symbol Yb) with an atomic number of 70.
a soft silvery metallic element; a rare earth of the lanthanide series; it occurs in gadolinite and monazite and xenotime

ytterite.explanation: chem. , of the same class as yttria.

yttria.explanation: A metallic oxid or earth, having the appearance of a white powder, which is insipid, insoluble in water, and infusible.
The oxide, Y2O3, or earth, of yttrium.

yttrialite.explanation: A silicate of thorium and the yttrium earths, occurring in massive forms of a dark olive-green color. It is found with gadolinite and other rare species in Llano county, Texas.
A rare, highly radioactive yttrium thorium sorosilicate mineral with conchoidal fracture .

yttric.explanation: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, yttrium.

yttriferous.explanation: Bearing or containing yttrium or the allied elements.

yttrious.explanation: yttric ; of or pertaining to yttrium

yttrium.explanation: A silvery metallic element, not a rare earth but occurring in nearly all rare-earth minerals, used in various metallurgical applications, notably to increase the strength of magnesium and aluminum alloys. Its oxide and other compounds are useful as phosphors, microwave filters, laser dopants, and superconducting materials. Atomic number 39; atomic weight 88.906; melting point 1,522°C; boiling point 3,345°C; specific gravity 4.469 (at 25°C); valence 3. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
Chemical symbol, Y; atomic weight, 89 (?). A metal, the base of the earth yttria.
A rare metallic element of the boron-aluminium group, found in gadolinite and other rare minerals, and extracted as a dark gray powder. Symbol Y. Atomic number 39. Atomic weight, 88.9.
A metallic chemical element (symbol Y) with an atomic number of 39.
a silvery metallic element that is common in rare-earth minerals; used in magnesium and aluminum alloys

yttrocerite.explanation: A violet-blue mineral, a hydrous fluoride of cerium , yttrium , and calcium .

yttrocrasite.explanation: A complex titanate of yttrium, thorium, uranium, and other elements. It occurs in the form of rough crystals (orthorhombic?) having a black color and pitchy luster, in Burnet county, Texas.

yttrogummite.explanation: A mineral formed by the alteration of cleveite, and related to it as is ordinary gummite to uraninite.

yttrotantalite.explanation: A rare mineral found at Ytterby, Sweden, of a black or brown color. It is a tantalate of yttrium, uranium, and iron, with calcium.
A brown or black tantalate of uranium , yttrium , and calcium .

yuan.explanation: The basic unit of money in China.

yucateco.explanation: a member of the Mayan people of the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico
a Mayan language spoken by the Yucatec

yucca.explanation: Any of various evergreen plants of the genera Yucca and Hesperoyucca of the southern United States, Mexico, and Central America, having stiff sword-shaped leaves, clusters of white flowers, and sometimes a thick treelike stem.

The name given in western South America to Manihot Aipi (see Manioc ). The latter name is not known in Peru and Chile or Bolivia, only ‘yuca’ being used. It is extensively consumed as a vegetable. The name is also common throughout Central America.
A plant of the genus Yucca.
[ capitalized ] [NL. (Dillenius, 1719).] A genus of liliaceous plants, of the tribe Dracæneæ.

A genus of American liliaceous, sometimes arborescent, plants having long, pointed, and often rigid, leaves at the top of a more or less woody stem, and bearing a large panicle of showy white blossoms.
a small silvery moth ( Pronuba yuccasella ) whose larvæ feed on plants of the genus Yucca.
Any of several evergreen plants , of the genus Yucca , having long, pointed, and rigid leaves at the top of a woody stem, and bearing a large panicle of showy white blossoms.
any of several evergreen plants of the genus Yucca having usually tall stout stems and a terminal cluster of white flowers; warmer regions of North America

yuck.explanation: Used to express rejection or strong disgust.
an interjection expressing repugnance or distaste.
a laugh; also, a joke or gag; -- usually used in the plural, .
Uttered to indicate disgust usually toward an objectionable taste or odour.
the sound made by a laugh

yuckel.explanation: Same as yockel for hickwall. Also yukkel .

yucker.explanation: The flicker, or golden-winged woodpecker, of eastern North America, Colaptes auratus. See cut under flicker .

yuckier.explanation: comparative form of yucky : more yucky

yuckiest.explanation: superlative form of yucky : most yucky .

yucky.explanation: Of something highly offensive; causing aversion or disgust .
highly offensive; arousing aversion or disgust

yug.explanation: One of the ages into which the Hindus divide the duration or existence of the world.
Any one of the four ages, Krita , or Satya , Treta , Dwapara , and Kali , into which the Hindoos divide the duration or existence of the world.
Archaic form of yuga (any of the religious ages in Hinduism).

yuga.explanation: In Hindu theology, an epoch or era within a cycle of four ages: the Satya Yuga (or Krita Yuga), the the Dvapara Yuga, the Treta Yugaand finally the Kali Yuga , with incremental lengths ranging from 432,000 to 1,728,000 years.

yugoslavian.explanation: of or relating to or characteristic of the former country of Yugoslavia or its people or languages
a native or inhabitant of Yugoslavia

yuk.explanation: One, such as a joke, that causes such a laugh.
One, such as a joke, that causes such a laugh.

yukata.explanation: A lightweight informal kimono, usually made of cotton.

yukked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of yuk .

yukkel.explanation: Another spelling of yuckel for hickwall.

yulan.explanation: A deciduous Chinese tree (Magnolia denudata) often cultivated for its large, cup-shaped, fragrant white flowers.
A Chinese magnolia, Magnolia conspicua , with abundant large white flowers, appearing in spring before the leaves.
A species of Magnolia ( Magnolia conspicua ) with large white blossoms that open before the leaves. See the Note under magnolia .
A species of magnolia with large white blossoms that open before the leaves .

yuletide.explanation: Alternative spelling of Yuletide . Christmas or the Christmas season.
A common name for the flower Camellia sasanqua native to Japan and nearby islands.

yum.explanation: Used to express appreciation of or eagerness for a tasty food or beverage.
Used to express appreciation for something attractive or to express eagerness for a pleasurable experience.
An expression used to indicate delight in regard to a certain food's flavor

yummier.explanation: comparative form of yummy : more yummy

yummiest.explanation: superlative form of yummy : most yummy .

yummy.explanation: Very pleasing to the taste or smell; delicious. synonym : delicious .
very pleasing or attractive; especially, pleasing to the taste; delicious; scrumptious.
extremely pleasing to the sense of taste

yunca.explanation: An Indian of a linguistic stock of tribes of the Peruvian coast who had a developed agricultural civilization at the advent of the Spaniards, before which they had been conquered by the Incas. They constructed irrigation canals which are still in use, adorned their buildings with bas-reliefs and frescoes, and were skilled goldsmiths and silversmiths.

yuppie.explanation: A young city or suburban resident with a well-paid professional job and an affluent lifestyle.

an ambitious young adult, usually college-educated, living in or near a large city, with a professional career and an affluent lifestyle. The "u" in the word is sometimes interpreted as meaning “upwardly mobile”.
a young upwardly mobile urban professional person with an affluent lifestyle
a young upwardly mobile professional individual; a well-paid middle-class professional who works in a city and has a luxurious life style

yuruk.explanation: a kind of Turkish rug from Konya and Karaman regions.

yus.explanation: Either of two letters, little yus ( Ѧ ) and big yus (Ѫ), representing nasal vowel sounds in the Cyrillic alphabet. The only Slavic language retaining these sounds is Polish , which is written in the Latin alphabet. Modern languages thus have little yus for them.

yutu.explanation: A species of tinamou, found in Peru.
